journal-title-group.journal-title: Indian Journal of Community Medicine: Official Publication of Indian Association of Preventive & Social Medicine

title-group.article-title: Child Immunization during COVID-19: A Mixed Methods Case Study of Pathanamthitta District, Kerala

article-meta.aff: Centre of Social Medicine and Community Health, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi, India

author-notes.corresp: Address for correspondence: Ms. Liz M. Kuriakose, Centre of Social Medicine and Community Health, Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi - 110 067, India. E-mail: lizmkuriakose@gmail.com

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Child immunization is a critical public health intervention to reduce the risk of infectious diseases. However, emergencies from disease, calamity, or conflict significantly disrupt the provision of immunization services through the primary healthcare system. This study aims to assess the impact of the Coronavirus Disease-2019 (COVID-19) pandemic on routine immunization in selected public health facilities in Pathanamthitta district, Kerala, and understand aspects of planning and service delivery and the perspectives of primary stakeholders.

sec.title: Materials and Methods:
sec.p: This mixed methods study of concurrent nested design in a Critical Realist paradigm assesses immunization patterns of 292 two-year-olds who sought routine immunization in 2020 and 2021. Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics in SPSS v. 16, and thematic analysis was performed on qualitative data. Triangulation of results involved comparing both datasets to generate a discussion of themes corresponding to immunization coverage and outcomes.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Immunization coverage across vaccines dropped in March 2020, followed by intense catching-up efforts in the subsequent months. Median delays in immunization uptake in the sample during the state lockdown (42 days) were higher than those experienced during the national lockdown (25 days). COVID-induced anxiety in parents, physical infrastructure, and accessibility of the health centers determined children’s right to vaccines during the pandemic.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Decontextualized guidelines, continuation with existing microplans, infrastructural deficiencies, and poor vaccine perceptions of parents/guardians triggered delays in vaccine uptake and a far-from-perfect immunization service delivery. Programme planning and implementation issues should be mitigated to prepare for future health emergencies without disrupting immunization services.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The utility of immunization arises from the biomedical understanding that children under 5 years are highly vulnerable to life-threatening diseases. Routine immunization is the safest means of protection from severe infections by reducing morbidity and mortality, inducing herd immunity, reducing the occurrence of secondary infections, and eradication.[1] Twenty-three million children missed essential childhood vaccines via routine services with the onset of the Coronavirus Disease-2019 (COVID-19) pandemic.[2] Among the middle-income countries that fared poorly on vaccination coverage, India had the most significant increase in children failing to receive the first dose of the Diphtheria-Pertussis-Tetanus (DPT) vaccine (3,038,000 in 2020 as compared to 1,403,000 in 2019).[2] As Henrietta Fore said, “The pandemic has made a bad situation worse”.[2]

During this unanticipated emergency, child immunization was affected by the imposition of restrictive lockdowns and the creation of containment zones,[34] parental reluctance to visit health centers,[5678] lack of insurance,[7] poor socioeconomic conditions, and low awareness levels.[6] Many parents underestimated the pandemic’s longevity and decided to postpone vaccinations or perceived it as ‘non-essential’.[9] Furthermore, the pandemic exposed the inherent weaknesses of the health system, leading to the suspension of immunization programs,[3510] staff remobilization to COVID care,[3411121314] supply chain disruptions and vaccine stock-outs,[35610] and growing fear among health workers[456] amid personal protective equipment (PPE) shortages.[3] Discussion on a rights-based approach to healthcare is crucial for child wellbeing during a pandemic.[15] Child health is affected by social isolation, school closures, delayed/missed medical care, family stress, and the absence of state safeguarding structures. Apart from being a societal need, protection from Vaccine-Preventable Diseases (VPD) is a child’s fundamental right.[13]

Kerala’s development model is renowned for its people-centric policies. The history of immunization in the region traces back to 1879, when a royal proclamation mandated compulsory immunizations for students, prisoners, and public servants.[16] The ‘Kerala model’ of pandemic response[1718] received excellent traction during COVID-19. However, the emphasis on pandemic management reduced focus on other health services, particularly child health, whereby the state recorded a drop in routine immunization by 2.3%.[19]

Pathanamthitta in South Kerala is a 90% rural-based, landlocked district with a very low acute multidimensional poverty,[20] a negative population growth rate,[21] 99.1% institutional deliveries,[22] and 99.7% female literacy.[22] Though initial COVID-19 cases in Kerala reported from Pathanamthitta created a great furore, eventually, the district was hailed for its model of pandemic management involving proactive care for high-risk groups at the community level, a three-tier system to prevent quarantine violations and so on.[2324] How the district managed the provision of child health services, mainly routine immunization, in this period is intriguing. Very few public health studies have been conducted in Pathanamthitta as most of the immunization research is concentrated in North Kerala.
Therefore, this district-based, exploratory public health case study in Kerala seeks to:

list-item.p: Assess the impact of the pandemic on the routine child immunization program in selected public healthcare facilities in Pathanamthitta district.

Understand aspects of planning and service delivery at these health centers and gather the perspectives of health workers and parents/guardians on their experiences with immunization during the pandemic.

sec.title: Methodological paradigm: Critical Realism
sec.p: This paradigm emphasizes ‘context’, which triggers specific mechanisms that produce social action. An attempt is made in this study to theorize explanations for the disruptive tendencies in seeking immunization as observed/experienced during the pandemic in Pathanamthitta. These explanations focus on the mechanisms underlying the significant entities involved in the immunization system (health service system and community) that respond to crises and the properties of these entities that empower them with such mechanisms.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: Mixed Methods Case Study of Concurrent Nested Design.

The realist paradigm promotes the adoption of methodological pluralism.[25] As an exploratory exercise in the district, qualitative experiences and quantitative outcomes were examined in-depth via a case-study approach. Considering the busy schedules of the respondents and the dynamic nature of the pandemic, quantitative and qualitative data were collected simultaneously in one data collection phase (concurrent).[26] Triangulation of results from both datasets was possible in a single study. In this nested design, the secondary method of data collection, ‘qualitative’ (qual), was embedded within the primary ‘Quantitative’ (QUAN) method as [QUAN (qual)].[27] While the quantitative method addressed immunization program outcomes (coverage, delays, and vaccination-specific indicators), qualitative data explored the immunization process and the contextual experiences of stakeholders.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: Children born between March and December 2019 registered with public health facilities for immunization and would have faced disruptions in access to the service during the lockdowns. The total live births in Pathanamthitta between March and December 2019 were 13,699.[28]

Inclusion Criteria: Children born between March 1, 2019 and December 31, 2019 (inclusive of these dates) and registered with and securing immunization services at the selected Primary Health Centres/Family Health Centres (PHC/FHC) in Ranny, Mallappally, and Thiruvalla taluks of the district and children who are immunized at the centers mentioned above as per the government policy of vaccination.

Exclusion Criteria: Children born before March 1, 2019 and after December 31, 2019 or securing immunization from private health centers in the district and children not registered with the selected PHC/FHC and/or being immunized differently from the government vaccination policy.

sec.title: Sampling framework
sec.p: The concurrent mixed-methods sampling design involved multistage random sampling and purposive sampling. In multistage sampling, three out of six taluks (namely, Mallappally, Ranny, and Thiruvalla) were selected for their differences in terrain. Of the 20 PHC/FHCs in these taluks, five were randomly selected [with at most five Sub-centres (SC) under each PHC/FHC]. At least ten children of the target age group visiting these SCs for immunization were considered. The ideal sample size of children was estimated at 310. Of this sample, at least 30 parents/guardians were to be interviewed using purposive sampling based on the criteria of geographical terrain in which they reside (highland, midland, or lowland) that determined their accessibility to the nearest health center.
Sample Size: 292 two-year-old children.
Timeline of Data Collection: December 2021 to March 2022.

p.bold: Data Parameters, Respondents, and Instruments of Data Collection: Table 1.

2. Understand aspects of planning and service delivery at these health centres as well as gather perspectives of health workers and parents/guardians on their experiences with immunization during the pandemic.

Process of microplanning (stakeholders involved, area demarcation, sensitization and review meetings, local COVID-risk assessment, modification of micro-plans, site selection, preparation of line lists, emergency plans, modified supervision/monitoring frameworks etc.) Service delivery (time slot allotment, beneficiary mobilization, safety measures, private sector & local self-government engagements, priority vaccines, health education, etc.) Personal observations of parents/guardians on the immunization process during and after lockdown (safety measures, infrastructure experiences of delay in vaccine uptake, etc.)
i-ii. Medical Officers [MO] & JPHNs iii. Parents/guardians of the beneficiaries
Interview Schedule (I) [MOs] Survey Questionnaire [JPHNs] Interview Schedule (II) [For Parents]

sec.title: Data collection process
sec.p: Prior permission for research was obtained from the District Medical Officer in November 2021. A small pilot test was conducted at a PHC to modify the research tools and understand the information that would be divulged to the researcher. Informed consent was obtained from the respondents in the local language (Malayalam) before the interviews. Data were collected from official records and ten Junior Public Health Nurses (JPHN) on the immunization service delivery using a survey questionnaire. Interactions with JPHNs occurred during their relatively less busy working hours or breaks. Thirty parents/guardians were interviewed at the health centers before or after their child’s immunization. Four consenting Medical Officers (MOs) were interviewed to understand the microplanning process during the pandemic in detail.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Quantitative data were analyzed using SPSS 16.0 for descriptive statistics. Vaccines that qualify children as ‘fully immunized’ and the following periods were considered in the assessments involving immunization coverages:

list-item.p: National Lockdown – March, April and May 2020 + June 2020 (to compare with June 2021)
Corresponding months in the last non-COVID year – March, April, May and June 2019

sec.p: Immunization coverage attained for each vaccine in the selected month is calculated as:

Coverage attained per vaccine (%) = [{Number of doses of the vaccine administered in the selected month}/{Number of children eligible to take the vaccine in the selected month (based on monthly live birth data}]*100

Vaccines administered simultaneously were combined into a single variable in this study [e.g., the uptake of the first doses of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), Liquid Pentavalent Vaccine (LPV), and Rotavirus Vaccine (RVV) at 6 weeks of life is denoted as OPV_LPV_RVV_1]. The maximum number of vaccine doses administered per session was estimated as the product of the number of children attending a session and the maximum possible doses of vaccines that can be given at a time (based on nurses’ inputs).

Qualitative data from providers’ perspectives, observations, and field notes were analyzed. The narratives of parents/guardians were weaved through a simple thematic analysis. Open coding of interview extracts was done in Microsoft Word, followed by pattern identification and generation of themes in Microsoft Excel.

sec.title: Data integration
sec.p: The embedded qualitative data support the quantitative data in interpreting results. Both datasets were analyzed separately. The final triangulation of results in the analysis phase involved both sets of results being compared, resulting in a discussion of the themes in the context of the outcomes of the immunization process.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: This study was approved by the Institutional Ethics Review Board (IERB) of Jawaharlal Nehru University, New Delhi (IERB Ref No. 2021/M.Phil Student/282).

sec.title: Immunization uptake of the sample of 2-year-old children
sec.p: On assessing the delay (in days) in the uptake of scheduled vaccines by the sample, it was found that the median delay in 2019 (98 days) was higher than the corresponding delays experienced during the lockdown and unlock phases in 2020 [25 and 35 days, respectively] and 2021 [42 and 48 days, respectively] [Table 2]. Delays in both phases of 2021 were higher than those reported in 2020. This is attributed to the anxiety among parents about getting their children vaccinated during the severe COVID-19 wave in Kerala in 2021 (despite uninterrupted immunization service delivery). A large number of children had delayed intake of the first dose of the Measles-Rubella (MR) vaccine (and Vitamin A) and the second dose of the MR vaccine, along with booster doses of DPT and OPV (and Vitamin A) in 2020 and 2021, respectively. Some individual values of delay reported from this sample go beyond 250 days. This implies delaying vaccination uptake after obtaining the doses mandated for the first 6 months of life.

sec.title: Cumulative Immunization Coverages of the PHC/FHCs during Selected Months of 2019, 2020, and 2021
sec.p: In the selected PHC/FHCs, the cumulative median immunization coverage (across vaccines given in the first year of life) in March 2020 stood at 37.5% for Vitamin A and 39% for MR to a high of 67% for second doses of OPV, LPV, and RVV [Table 3]. In April 2020, 100% coverage was attained across vaccines except for Vitamin A. In May 2020, more than 78% coverage was attained for these vaccines, and the state lockdown months witnessed more than 70% vaccination coverage across these health centers. In April 2020, 68 more children received appropriate doses [Table S1].

caption.p: Overall Coverage (%) for Specific Antigens Administered in the First Year of Birth in All the Selected PHC/FHCs during 2019 and Lockdown Months (2020 and 2021)4 [Original]

fn.p: 1DPT_1B, Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus First Booster dose; IPV, Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine; MR, Measles Rubella Vaccine; OPV_LPV_RVV, Oral Poliovirus Vaccine, Liquid Pentavalent Vaccine, Rotavirus Vaccine administered at 6, 10 & 14 weeks of birth; OPV_B, Oral Poliovirus Vaccine Booster dose; VIT_A, Vitamin A; The dosage of each vaccine is indicated in Arabic numerals after the underscore symbol

sec.p: Between March 2020 and March 2019, a fall in uptake of 22.5% to 50% was estimated across different vaccines (except in second doses of OPV, LPV, and RVV) [Table S2]. Subsequent months of the national lockdown saw coverages higher than their previous-year counterparts, with a few exceptions of negative trends in Vitamin A (April 2020 vs April 2019) and the first doses of OPV, LPV, RVV, and the Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine (IPV) (May 2020 vs May 2019). Mixed trends prevailed when comparing state lockdown months to their previous-year counterparts. Trends were negative for the vaccines given to children under 4 months old.

caption.p: Difference in Coverage (%) of Specific Antigens between 2019, 2020 National Lockdown and 2021 State Lockdown Months of All PHC/FHCs2 [Original]

tr.th: Difference in coverage of specific antigens between selected time periods

fn.p: 2DPT_1B, Diphtheria Pertussis Tetanus First Booster dose; IPV, Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine; MR, Measles Rubella Vaccine; OPV_LPV_RVV, Oral Poliovirus Vaccine, Liquid Pentavalent Vaccine, Rotavirus Vaccine administered at 6, 10 & 14 weeks of birth; OPV_B, Oral Poliovirus Vaccine Booster dose; VIT_A, Vitamin A; The dosage of each vaccine is indicated in Arabic numerals after the underscore symbol

sec.title: Planning and service delivery
sec.p: Immunization service delivery at health centers changed with the pandemic’s onset in 2020. Around six sessions (average) could not be conducted as planned between March and May 2020. However, services were not disrupted during the state lockdown.

Sessions were held according to the guidelines issued by the central, state, and district health authorities, and areas were categorized into zones1 based on prevailing COVID-19 cases. Online training on COVID management for health workers did not include any specific module on child immunization. The annual microplans prepared in February–early March 2020 were carried forward without pandemic-specific modifications. Pandemic-related safety guidelines were incorporated into service delivery without documenting a context-appropriate plan for implementation.

While sessions were suspended in containment and buffer zones, 23 and 24 children, on average, were vaccinated at the health facilities and outreach centers in Beyond Buffer and Green Zones, respectively. Partially and unimmunized children under 5 years were prioritized at all centers. Significant changes in service delivery included the introduction of a slot-based appointment system, physical distancing, adoption of safety measures (masks, gloves, sanitisers, PPEs), permissible entry of only one caregiver per beneficiary in the immunization room, individual health education/counseling, and local COVID-19 assessments before organizing sessions. MOs screened children for flu or other illnesses and inquired about any COVID cases in the family before vaccination. Local self-government and the private sector were not involved in routine immunization at the public health centers.

sec.title: Logistics
sec.p: There were timely vaccine deliveries from the block level as per PHC/FHC requirements varying from once a month to once every 3 months. No major hassles were reported in vaccine delivery (except for shortages in Vitamin A syrups in May and June 2020) or cold chain systems across these centers. Vaccine wastage was minimal as JPHNs opened vials based on the number of children to be vaccinated.

sec.title: Staffing
sec.p: During the pandemic, staffing was done prudently to avoid virus transmission and minimize fears of human interaction. At the health facilities, every immunization session was held with the near availability of an MO and managed by two JPHNs (one for vaccine administration and the other for record-keeping) and one Junior Health Inspector (JHI). Two Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) facilitated the entry and exit of beneficiaries from the immunization room and mobilized caregivers for the next visit. At the outreach centers, sessions were manned by an MO, a JHI, a JPHN, and an ASHA. Only healthy nurses and ASHAs were mandated to attend sessions, and additional vaccinators were not hired. No shortages of essential safety items were reported in these centres.

sec.title: Information, Education, and Communication (IEC)
sec.p: Due to restrictions imposed on interpersonal contact and movement during lockdowns, the primary mode of IEC was telephones and Short Messaging Service (SMS) technology to reach parents/guardians. As the situation eased, ASHAs began house visits when required.

sec.title: Outcomes of immunization process
sec.p: The maximum number of doses administered per session was 60 (range: 45, 105) [Figure S1]. Infrastructure, geographical accessibility, and COVID-19 zone-based restrictions determined the provision of immunization services during the lockdowns. The average period of disruption of immunization was 4.2 weeks across these centers during the national lockdown [Table S3]. Apart from the mandated suspension in March 2020, one PHC had to halt services due to heavy rains and subsequent floods. By May–June 2021, services were regularized at all centers. No severe/serious Adverse Events Following Immunization cases were reported at any health center.

caption.p: Average Disruption in Immunization during the National Lockdown across the PHC/FHCs [Original]

sec.title: Personal experiences of beneficiary parents/guardians
sec.p: Among the 30 parents/guardians interviewed, an equal percentage of respondents (36.67%) expressed relief and anxiety upon receiving information about the resumption of immunization services after the national lockdown (the remaining 26.67% were indifferent) [Figure S2]. Analyzing their responses resulted in decoding three themes and associated codes [Table S4].

caption.p: Themes and associated Codes derived from Responses of Beneficiary Parents/Guardians [Original]

tr.td: Fear, Mistrust and Disappointment with Public Health Facilities

list-item.p: Anxiety and fear of high-risk environments
Infrastructure deficiencies of the health centres
Provision of general services with immunization
Awareness and understanding of health interventions

sec.title: Theme 1: Fear, mistrust, and disappointment with public health facilities
sec.p: As quoted in Figure 1, some respondents expressed fear and anxiety about bringing their children to health centers, particularly those with infrastructural constraints during COVID-19. Their concerns pertained to overcrowding and congestion at the health centers with limited waiting areas, an abrupt halt to the provision of general health services at SCs on immunization days, and the inability of young children to abide by safety measures such as wearing masks for extended periods.

caption.p: Parental Responses on Child Immunization during COVID-19 in the Study Location [Original]

sec.title: Theme 2: Accessibility, awareness, and acceptability
sec.p: Irrespective of socioeconomic backgrounds, an equal number of respondents (as those who expressed fear) were relieved with the resumption of immunization services and trusted the public health facilities. Some mothers who were health professionals considered vaccination an essential health intervention for children that must be completed on time. These mothers acknowledged their shared responsibility (with the health workers) to protect their children in high-risk environments. The health center’s location was a critical factor in accessing services, particularly if the child was cared for by grandparents [Figure 1].

sec.title: Theme 3: Coping with challenges
sec.p: Sixteen respondents discussed different aspects of the streamlined immunization service delivery and the health workers’ vigilance after resuming services in April 2020. These included time-slot allotment, shorter waiting periods and reduced crowding outside immunization rooms, running immunization sessions away from the OPD in most PHC/FHCs, screening for flu and other illnesses, receipt of timely information on the imminent immunization dates from JPHN/ASHA, individual health education/counseling by health workers, provision of hand sanitizers, and physical distancing [Figure 1].

sec.title: Summary of the results
sec.p: Child immunization coverage picked up in the selected health centers after the initial dip in March 2020. The delays in vaccine uptake were higher during the state lockdown in 2021 than the national lockdown in 2020, implying the response of anxious parents during the severe COVID-19 wave in 2021. Higher median delays in vaccine uptake in 2019 could mean a lapse on the part of the health system in following up with beneficiary households. Planning and service delivery of immunization suffered due to a greater emphasis on COVID-19 management at the grassroots level. Undertaking service delivery in the new circumstances with existing plans was a far-from-perfect approach. The health centers utilized their existing capacities to avoid technical glitches in vaccine logistics, staffing, and IEC activities. Parents/guardians, as non-passive actors, appreciated and expressed their grievances regarding the service delivery. Even as infrastructural deficiencies in health centers remained unaddressed, the new streamlined approach and vigilance of the health workers ought to be taken forward even when COVID-19 no longer persists as a threat.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: As Critical Realist research, this study discusses the underlying mechanisms behind the results obtained. It highlights certain factors that led to a far-from-perfect immunization service delivery in the district.

Table 4 corroborates the disconnect between the guidelines issued and the ground reality of the selected health centers. The ‘one-size-fits-all’ set of guidelines did not account for disparities in health infrastructure across states and districts. Infrastructural deficiencies obstructed adherence to safety measures at the health centers, causing dissatisfaction among parents/guardians. Preparing context-based plans incorporating administrative guidelines and their enforcement is vital to successfully implementing a public health program.

caption.p: Analysis of Disconnect between Guidelines and Reality of Immunization Service Delivery at the Selected PHC/FHCs of Pathanamthitta District, Kerala [Original]

tr.td: Ensure social distancing and hand washing etc., as outlined in the annexure, to be adopted at health facility level for vaccinating the pregnant women and children who have reported to these facilities[29] The immunization sessions can be restarted both in public and private institutions with strict directions to the intuitions2 for practicing all the components of the ‘break the chain’ instructions and strictly maintaining the social distancing without fail[30]

Using the term ‘social distancing’ instead of ‘physical distancing’ presents ethical concerns particularly during a public health emergency where social interactions are viewed with suspicion and fear. The preventive measure endorsed has been to maintain distant socialization with a sense of social inclusion, of unity in crisis and remaining connected via virtual communication technologies. In a socially diverse country like India, this term can foster distinction and discrimination in the name of distancing.

Pre-identification of a well-ventilated seating area with demarcated seating location 1 meter apart[29] Pre-identification of session site with adequate seating space for beneficiaries and caregivers while maintaining social distancing (at least 1-meter gap) with clear area of demarcation for incoming beneficiaries, post vaccination waiting area and a reserve zone if gathering increases[29] Social distancing shall be strictly followed in the waiting room, vaccination room as well as the observation room[30] In the waiting area, the chairs shall be kept at a distance of 1 meter from each other[30]

These pertain to physical distancing mandated at the health facility as well as at outreach session sites during immunization. However physical infrastructural deficiencies of the health centres were ignored. In the study district, most of the health centres lacked distinction between waiting room and observation room. Either it was a common space used interchangeably or none that existed.
In hospitals, immunization may be provided in an area away from the OP and IP wing. Preferably, a separate entrance away from the general patient entry may be arranged for the immunization area[30]

Though specific to a hospital, this guideline should be made applicable to the PHC/FHCs of the district where many residents frequent for out-patient care. In two PHC/FHCs visited, a common entrance led to the Out-Patient Department and immunization room. In one PHC, a greater risk of exposure of the beneficiaries to general patients existed as both waited for their turns in close proximity.

td.italic: Support from Panchayat/Urban Local Body to be sought for identification of appropriate session site with adequate space to practice social distancing (at least 1 meter)

tr.td: Local self-government bodies were involved in COVID-management activities along with health workers, but their role in supporting child immunization services by securing spacious session sites was not reported.

Alternate Session Sites: Site other than Anganwadi center may need to be identified in case of space constraints to maintain social/physical distancing and lack of adequate provision for hand washing with soap and water. Schools, Panchayat Ghars, community centers etc., may be explored as alternate sites[29]
None of the health centres mentioned alternate session sites to conduct immunization sessions. In view of infrastructural deficiencies at the health centres, this option could have been explored.

Ensure that beneficiaries and caregivers maintain the social distancing during the 30-minute waiting period. This 30-minute waiting period to be used for group counselling and avoid individual counselling. Provide key preventive messages related to COVID-19, (handwashing technique, nutrition of pregnant women, breastfeeding etc.)[29]

Brief individual health education was provided to caregivers during their child’s immunization. Group counselling sessions were avoided particularly as children were not capable of face-masking. Moreover, not all caregivers adhered to the waiting period after vaccination and preferred going home without exposing their children longer in the risky environment of a health centre.
Capacity building of front-line health workers: Instead of In-person trainings, existing digital health platforms may be leveraged for training and capacity building[29]
Though online trainings focused on COVID care and management were conducted, health workers indicated that there was no module on child immunization in these sessions.

States need to strengthen the supportive supervisory mechanism for VHSND/immunization sessions and to include monitoring of practices associated with social distancing and other guidelines. Data from SS should be used for local action and monitoring progress[29]
No information has been obtained on the existence of supportive supervisory mechanisms or monitoring of practices from any of the PHC/FHCs in the study.

fn.p: 2Could be ‘institutions’ (a possible typing error in the guidelines issued)

sec.p: The state government came under fire due to their lack of vigilance and enforcement of protective measures during festivals[31] and elections[3233] during COVID-19. The subsequent rise in COVID-19 cases in the months following the elections resulted in a drop in the district’s routine immunization coverage (particularly among children under 4 months old). Inconsistencies between government policies and their implementation in a health emergency can result in relapses, regardless of the resilience of the public health system.

As India marches toward MR elimination goals and seeks to attain more than 95% coverage in two doses of MR vaccination,[34] delaying MR shots (and Vitamin A supplementation) will lead to a retreat in achievements. Personal observations and administrative data from the health centers indicate that children’s uptake of the remaining seven doses of Vitamin A largely depends on the convenience of parents/guardians. Communication and education strategies should be appropriately framed and implemented to change perceptions toward different vaccines (particularly MR) and assert their significance in child health. These vaccinations must be monitored with elimination targets for delays and avoidance.

sec.title: Strengths of the study
sec.p: The study’s methodological paradigm and design enabled a multifaceted exploration of child immunization processes and perspectives in the selected health centers. Though this is research on a vulnerable group, ‘children’, their direct participation was not solicited. The in-person mode of data collection enabled the gathering of contextual information about the health centers and the corroboration of qualitative findings with quantitative and observational inputs. Research fatigue was not observed among the respondents because only few public health studies have been conducted in this district. The triangulation of evidence ensured internal validity via different tools from multiple sources. The utility criterion was fulfilled by evaluating almost all aspects of the program.

sec.title: Limitations of the study
sec.p: Unequal sample sizes would have revealed less of the study’s qualitative aspects than quantitative. Due to difficulties following up on a child through the immunization registers for 3 years, the data of only 292 children could be secured. Some parents/guardians’ responses may have been influenced by the location of the interview and the presence of health workers in the vicinity. Despite multiple visits to the health centers, it was only possible to interview 30 parents/guardians. This was because fewer beneficiaries of the selected age group came to receive their Vitamin A supplementation at the time of data collection. Last, the generalizability of the findings of this study is limited as the results are specific to the context of the public health centers in this district.

sec.title: Recommendations for future research
sec.p: Future studies could replicate this research on a larger scale, including public and private health facilities, to provide a broader picture of child immunization in the district. Immunization outcomes and delays in coverage of children of higher age groups may be examined. Assessments on the effectiveness of IEC tools deployed, VPD surveillance mechanisms, and monitoring and evaluation frameworks of the health centers would provide more specific insights into the program.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: Routine immunization is a critical service to child health that cannot be disregarded during a public health emergency. The study results convey disruptions to immunization services and delays experienced by 2-year-old children in their appropriate vaccine uptakes during the pandemic. Discrepancies in the preparation of guidelines, planning, service delivery, and community engagement precipitated less than complete coverage of most vaccines and significant outliers of delay. Fear of contracting COVID-19 and physical infrastructural deficiencies of the health centers influenced parental decisions. Therefore, it is recommended that the issues in program planning and implementation be rectified and the lessons learned be carried forward to prepare for future health emergencies without disrupting immunization services.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: There are no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: I would like to express my gratitude to Dr. Rajib Dasgupta, Professor, Centre for Social Medicine and Community Health, Jawaharlal Nehru University for guiding me through this MPhil Dissertation. I am also grateful to the District Medical Officer of Pathanamthitta for granting permission to conduct this study in the selected health centres. Sincere thanks to the Medical Officers, Health Inspectors, JPHNs and ASHAs of the selected PHC/FHCs as well as parents/guardians of beneficiaries for their time and contribution to this study.
